learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate in-depth knowledge of the chemical structures, properties, and functions of major food components.
Demonstrate a sound knowledge of the integrated behaviour of food systems.
Use knowledge of functional and chemical properties of food to describe the most appropriate procedure required for a particular food analysis problem.

Work individually or as part of a team to illustrate how lab techniques could be used to solve experimental problems involving the accurate quantification and characterisation of the physical and chemical properties of food and beverages.
Communicate experimental results of food analyses in written form.

assessments.task_description:
Examinable material includes Water, Carbohydrates, Amino acids, Proteins, Enzymes, and Tutorials ONLY.

Students will have 1 hour to complete the exam once started.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date:
Formative practical lab workbook (Weighting: 0%, Pass/ Fail) 17/04/2025 2:00 pm

Final practical lab workbook (Weighting: 30%) 23/05/2025 2:00 pm
assessments.task_description:
Students will keep one practical lab notebook, electronically provided by the Lab coordinator via Blackboard, which will be submitted via Turnitin for a formative assessment.

Students will be able to utilise the feedback provided from this submission to improve their end-of-semester practical lab book submission. 

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills, and knowledge without the aid of artificial intelligence (AI) or machine translation (MT) tools. Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
All material taught is examinable (Practicals, Tutorials, Lectures).

The exam will be an on-campus exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.

Students enrolled in In Person delivery must attend the exam in-person. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Food Chemistry Lectures

Contains lectures on the structure and functions of food components and systems. Reactions and interactions of food components, particularly related to degradative processes. Introduction to the chemical analysis of foods using modern analytical chemistry techniques.

Readings/Ref: Blackboard; Library website


Sub-activity: Water; Carbohydrates; Amino acids and proteins; Food enzymes; Lipids; Introduction to food analysis; Browning; Vitamins and minerals; Colour; and Flavour chemistry

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Food Chemistry Lectures Contains lectures on the structure and functions of food components and systems. Reactions and interactions of food components, particularly related to degradative processes. Introduction to the chemical analysis of foods using modern analytical chemistry techniques. Readings/Ref: Blackboard; Library website Sub-activity: Water; Carbohydrates; Amino acids and proteins; Food enzymes; Lipids; Introduction to food analysis; Browning; Vitamins and minerals; Colour; and Flavour chemistry

Readings/Ref: Blackboard; Library website
